fullProgramDescription: The Department of Mechanical Engineering offers a program leading to the degree of Bachelor of Science in Mechanical Engineering. The program is designed to provide a broad foundation in the fundamental principles of mechanical engineering, as well as to introduce students to the latest advances in the field. Students develop a strong background in mathematics, physics, and engineering sciences, and learn to apply these principles to solve real-world problems.
shortProgramDescription: The Mechanical Engineering program at MIT provides a comprehensive education in the principles of mechanical engineering, preparing students for a wide range of careers in industry, government, and academia.
classHighlights: Core Subjects: The program includes core subjects such as Mechanics, Materials Science, Thermodynamics, Fluid Mechanics, and Dynamics and Control, providing a solid foundation in the fundamental principles of mechanical engineering.

Mathematics and Physics: Students take a range of mathematics and physics courses, including Calculus, Differential Equations, and Physics, to develop a strong understanding of the underlying principles of mechanical engineering.

Engineering Sciences: The program includes a range of engineering science courses, such as Mechanics of Solids and Fluids, Thermodynamics, and Heat Transfer, that apply mathematical and scientific principles to solve engineering problems.
Mechanical Engineering Fundamentals: Students learn about the design, development, and testing of mechanical systems, including mechanical components, machines, and systems.
Departmental Electives: Students choose from a range of departmental electives to explore specialized topics in mechanical engineering, such as biomechanical engineering, energy systems, or robotics.
learningOutcomes: Apply fundamental principles of mechanical engineering to solve real-world problems.
Design, develop, and test mechanical systems and components.
Analyze and optimize mechanical systems using mathematical and computational tools.
Communicate technical information effectively through written and oral presentations.
Work effectively in teams to solve complex engineering problems.
Understand the social, economic, and environmental context of mechanical engineering practice.

creditRequirements: 180-192 units (total), with at least 72 units in mechanical engineering subjects
additionalInformation: Students must complete a range of General Institute Requirements, including mathematics, physics, and humanities courses, in addition to the mechanical engineering core subjects and departmental electives.
